choices.text: Drug A has a higher therapeutic index and is safer than Drug B
Drug B has a higher therapeutic index and is safer than Drug A
Both drugs have identical safety profiles
LD₅₀ values cannot be used to assess drug safety in clinical practice

questions.text:
A pharmaceutical company has developed two potential antihypertensive drugs. During preclinical toxicity testing in rats, the following data was obtained:

Drug A: LD₅₀ = 500 mg/kg, ED₅₀ = 10 mg/kg
Drug B: LD₅₀ = 200 mg/kg, ED₅₀ = 5 mg/kg

Based on this toxicological data, which statement is most accurate regarding drug safety?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Drug A has a higher therapeutic index and is safer than Drug B

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient weighing 50 kg is being treated for a chronic infection with an oral antibiotic that follows first-order kinetics. The drug has a clearance rate of 2 L/hour and a volume of distribution of 10 L in this patient. For effective therapy, a steady-state plasma concentration (Css) of 0.7 mg/L needs to be maintained. The drug is available only in oral formulation with a bioavailability (F) of 70%, and it is prescribed to be taken three times daily. What should be the dose per administration to maintain the desired plasma concentration?

choices.text: Inhibits carbonic anhydrase leading to metabolic alkalosis and improved oxygen delivery
Inhibits carbonic anhydrase causing metabolic acidosis and stimulating respiratory drive
Blocks sodium channels causing diuresis and reduced cerebral edema
Activates carbonic anhydrase increasing bicarbonate retention and buffering capacity

questions.text: A 45-year-old mountaineer is planning to climb to an altitude of 4,500 meters (14,800 feet) over 3 days. He has previously experienced headache, nausea, and fatigue during rapid ascents to high altitude. His physician prescribes a medication to prevent acute mountain sickness. The drug works by inhibiting an enzyme that catalyzes the hydration of carbon dioxide. Which of the following best describes the mechanism and clinical effect of this medication?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Inhibits carbonic anhydrase causing metabolic acidosis and stimulating respiratory drive

choices.text: Neprilysin inhibition and angiotensin receptor blockade
Direct positive inotropic action on myocardium

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with NYHA Class III heart failure despite optimal therapy with ACE inhibitor, β-blocker, and aldosterone antagonist is being considered for sacubitril-valsartan. The mechanism of benefit from this combination involves:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Neprilysin inhibition and angiotensin receptor blockade

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with newly diagnosed angina. His blood pressure is 148/94 mmHg. Medical history includes Type 2 diabetes mellitus with microalbuminuria and a previous myocardial infarction 8 months ago. His current medications include metformin and aspirin. Which antihypertensive agent addresses the most compelling indications in this patient?

A 60-year-old diabetic patient complains of marked alteration in blood glucose levels. His postprandial glucose levels reach 280 mg/dl, but fasting levels are around 120 mg/dl. Which medication would be most appropriate for this specific pattern?

choices.text: Stop warfarin for 5 days and repeat INR
Stop warfarin and give vitamin K 5-10 mg IM
Stop warfarin and give four-factor prothrombin complex concentrate

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation presents with epistaxis and active hematuria. Her INR is 6.5. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Stop warfarin and give four-factor prothrombin complex concentrate

choices.text: Send blood sample for CD 4 counts and HIV testing and begin post exposure prophylaxis with tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir after 72 hours irrespective of the CD4 count and HIV RNA levels.
Send blood sample for CD 4 counts and HIV testing and begin post exposure prophylaxis with tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir if CD4 count is low and HIV RNA is detectable.
Send blood sample for CD 4 counts and HIV testing and begin post exposure prophylaxis with two NRTIs and an integrate inhibitor immediately for 28 days.
Start HAART therapy immediately and continue life long.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents to medicine OPD with high-risk HIV exposure in a healthcare setting. Which management approach is most appropriate?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Send blood sample for CD4 counts and HIV testing and begin post exposure prophylaxis with two NRTIs and an integrase inhibitor immediately for 28 days.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient receiving cyclophosphamide, methotrexate and 5-Fluorouracil for breast cancer presents with severe fatigue and weakness. Laboratory investigations reveal: Hemoglobin: 5.5 g/dL, Total Leucocyte Count: 7000/mm³, Platelet Count: 180,000/mm³. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Add promethazine to control these symptoms

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with bronchial asthma and chronic schizophrenia has been on chlorpromazine for the past 6 months. Over the last few weeks, her family reports that she appears extremely restless, repeatedly gets up and walks around, cannot sit still, and complains of an “inner sense of tension.” On examination, she keeps shifting her legs and rocking back and forth while sitting. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for her current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Add promethazine to control these symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following drug is a PARP inhibitor is specifically indicated for BRCA-positive ovarian cancer as a recent advancement in targeted therapy?
A 40-year-old obese female presented with Schizophrenia. Which of the following antipsychotic drug causes least weight gain?

choices.text: The choice of antibiotic was not appropriate, and another class should have been selected.
The correct treatment would involve a different form of penicillin G, rather than benzathine.
There is no need for changes; the treatment administered is correct.
After the initial injection, a follow-up dose should be given after 7 days.

questions.text: A 29-year-old sexually active, HIV-negative male visits his healthcare provider with a painless sore on his inner lip and a non-itchy rash on the soles of his feet. He recalls having a non-tender ulcer on his scrotum about a month and a half ago, which resolved on its own. He receives an intramuscular injection of benzathine penicillin G and is discharged. How might the treatment approach for this patient have been modified?
questions.solution: Ans. C) There is no need for changes; the treatment administered is correct.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension is being considered for a new antihypertensive medication. His physician is weighing various options, taking into consideration their potential impact on plasma renin activity, which could have downstream effects on blood pressure control. All of the following drugs increase plasma renin activity except:

choices.text: An anti-arrhythmic drug with a plasma half-life of 10 seconds used for acute treatment of PSVT
An anti-inflammatory drug with a plasma half-life of 24 hr
A hypnotic drug with a plasma half-life of 2 hours
An antihypertensive with a plasma half-life of 3 hours

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be given in sustained release oral dosage form?
questions.solution: Ans. D) An antihypertensive with a plasma half-life of 3 hours

choices.text: Increase in pulmonary vascular resistance and decreased pulmonary blood flow
Decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance and increased pulmonary blood flow
Increase in right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus
Decrease in pulmonary venous return and cardiac output

questions.text: A newborn infant takes his first breath immediately after delivery. Which of the following physiological changes occurs in the circulation as a direct result of alveolar oxygenation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance and increased pulmonary blood flow

choices.text: Passive diffusion of hydrogen ions across the apical membrane
Hydrogen ion secretion via an ATP-driven proton pump stimulated by aldosterone
Hydrogen secretion through H⁺–K⁺ ATPase inhibited by aldosterone
Sodium secretion through an aldosterone-independent Na⁺/H⁺ exchanger

questions.text: Within the distal nephron, which of the following correctly describes the secretory function of α-intercalated cells?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Hydrogen ion secretion via an ATP-driven proton pump stimulated by aldosterone

choices.text: Activation of guanylate cyclase increasing cGMP levels
ADP ribosylation of Gsα leading to increased cAMP levels
Inhibition of Gsα resulting in decreased cAMP production
Blockade of adenylate cyclase reducing chloride secretion

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with profuse watery diarrhea after consuming seafood from a coastal region. The stool appears pale and watery without blood or mucus. Laboratory analysis confirms Vibrio cholerae infection. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) ADP ribosylation of Gsα leading to increased cAMP levels

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is primarily involved in static two-point discrimination?

Which of the following contributes to the latent period in a single muscle twitch? 

 

  1. Excitation-contraction coupling
  2. Opening of sodium channels on NMJ
  3. Transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to NMJ
  4. Pumping of calcium back to the sarcoplasmic reticulum

choices.text: Decreasing secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus
Increased synthesis of FSH in the anterior pituitary
Increasing the pulse frequency of LH release

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea and galactorrhea for the past several months. MRI of the brain reveals a pituitary adenoma. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated prolactin levels. Which of the following mechanisms best explains her menstrual irregularity?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Decreasing secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man has the following serum electrolyte values during evaluation:

  • Na⁺: 130 mmol/L
  • Cl⁻: 84 mmol/L
  • HCO₃⁻: 16 mmol/L

What is the calculated anion gap for this patient?

choices.text: B fibers are less susceptible to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
B fibers are more susceptible to compression than A fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to compression than B fibers

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with weakness and numbness in his right arm upon waking after falling asleep intoxicated with his arm draped over a chair. Neurological examination shows wrist drop and decreased sensation over the dorsum of the hand. Considering the properties of different nerve fiber types, which of the following statements correctly describes their relative susceptibility to pressure injury?
questions.solution: Ans. D) A fibers are more susceptible to compression than B fibers

choices.text: By promoting calcium absorption in the intestines
By increasing both osteoclastic activity and reducing renal calcium excretion
By enhancing phosphate absorption in the intestine

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with symptoms of hyperparathyroidism. Laboratory analysis shows elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH). The accompanying graph shows changes in plasma calcium and phosphate levels after administration of PTH. Which of the following mechanisms explains how PTH increases plasma calcium levels primarily?
questions.solution: Ans. C) By increasing both osteoclastic activity and reducing renal calcium excretion

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the sleep clinic with complaints of feeling unrefreshed after sleep and experiencing frequent awakenings. A polysomnography study is ordered, and the results show prominent features of sleep spindles and K-complexes. These findings are characteristic of which stage of sleep?

A 62-year-old man with a long history of ischemic cardiomyopathy presents with fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, and ankle swelling. Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. Which of the following compensatory mechanisms is most important in maintaining cardiac output in the short term?

A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) performs a spirometry test. During forced expiration, the pressure difference between the alveoli and the mouth (ΔP) is measured to be 8 cm H₂O, and the airflow (Q) is 2 L/sec. What is the airway resistance (R) in this patient?

A single postsynaptic neuron in the spinal cord receives approximately 400 synaptic inputs from 150 different sensory neurons that transmit peripheral sensory information after summation. Which of the following neural circuit arrangements best describes this phenomenon?

choices.text: Inhibition of Gs protein in collecting duct cells by lithium toxicity
Deficiency of aquaporin-2 water channels due to hypothalamic lesion
Overproduction of ADH due to small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man taking treatment for bipolar disorder presents with excessive thirst and frequent urination. Laboratory findings reveal normal plasma glucose and sodium levels, but a markedly low urine osmolality despite water deprivation. Administration of desmopressin fails to significantly increase urine concentration. Which of the following best explains this patient’s condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Inhibition of Gs protein in collecting duct cells by lithium toxicity

choices.text: Saturation of carrier-mediated transport mechanisms in the proximal tubule
Decreased glomerular filtration rate due to autoregulatory failure
Competitive inhibition of PAH filtration at the glomerulus
Decreased renal plasma flow with increasing PAH concentration

questions.text: A 35-year-old man participates in a renal physiology study evaluating tubular transport mechanisms. Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) is infused at varying plasma concentrations, and its rate of filtration, secretion, and excretion is measured. The data are plotted as shown in the figure. Which of the following best explains the plateau observed in the secretion curve?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Saturation of carrier-mediated transport mechanisms in the proximal tubule

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a three-month history of worsening, intermittent pain in his mid-thigh, which is worse at night and sometimes awakens him from sleep. Over the last two weeks, he has also developed localized swelling and tenderness over the area, accompanied by a low-grade fever. Blood tests show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). A subsequent core needle biopsy is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency after falling on his outstretched hand with a hyper-pronated forearm. He complains of severe pain in his elbow and forearm. On physical examination, there is marked swelling and tenderness around the elbow. He is unable to actively extend his fingers though retains wrist extension. A radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerves is/are involved?

A 28-year-old male construction worker is brought to the emergency after falling 15 feet and landing on his feet. He complains of severe back pain, is unable to sit up, and reports numbness and weakness in both legs. He has diminished sensation over the L3 and L4 dermatomes. Based on the mechanism of injury and characteristic radiographic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis for this vertebral injury?

choices.text: Radiation therapy followed by a CT-guided biopsy

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a history of estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancer, status post-mastectomy and hormonal therapy five years ago, presents to the orthopedic clinic. She reports a deep, constant, and increasing pain in her left proximal femur for the last three months, which is worse at night and unrelieved by rest. On examination, she has tenderness over the greater trochanter and slight antalgic gait. Based on the patient's history, symptoms, and radiographic findings, which of the following is the most appropriate initial orthopedic management step?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Radiation therapy and prophylactic fixation

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a known history of Gleason prostate adenocarcinoma presents to the orthopedics clinic with severe, persistent, mechanical, and rest pain in his lower back and right hip that has worsened over the past three months. Laboratory workup reveals an elevated Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA) and a markedly elevated Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP). Which of the following is the most appropriate description of the characteristic bony lesions seen on the radiograph?

A 45-year-old construction worker presents to the clinic with progressive weakness in his dominant right hand over the last month. He reports chronic, deep aching pain over the lateral aspect of his elbow and upper forearm. On physical examination, he demonstrates strong wrist extension against resistance. However, there is a noticeable finger drop. This clinical presentation of finger drop with preserved wrist extension, and no sensory loss is most indicative of entrapment or injury to which of the following structures?

A 55-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a 6-month history of bilateral hand and wrist pain. She reports that the stiffness in her hands is worst in the morning, lasting for approximately two hours, and has noticed symmetrical swelling. She is also complaining of new-onset neck stiffness. Laboratory results show a high ESR, C-reactive protein (CRP), and a positive anti-CCP antibody test. Given the patient's classic presentation of chronic, symmetrical swelling involving the small joints of the hands, severe morning stiffness, and positive anti-CCP antibodies, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old female school teacher presents with a three-month history of left shoulder pain. The pain is dull and aching at rest but becomes sharp and intense with certain movements. She is asked to actively abduct her arm and reports severe pain as her arm moves between approximately and of abduction, but the pain completely resolves once her arm is lifted above. The range of 60–70-degree abduction is painful. Neer's and Hawkins-Kennedy tests reproduce her pain. The specific pattern of pain described during active abduction—severe pain between and that disappears above this range—is the hallmark clinical presentation of which condition?

A 13-year-old obese boy presents with a 3-week history of a dull ache in his right knee that is worse after playing sports. He denies any direct trauma. On examination, he has a noticeable limp and reports pain in the knee, but motion testing of the knee is normal. When the hip is flexed to 90 degrees, his thigh externally rotates involuntarily. Passive internal rotation of the right hip is severely limited and painful. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE)

questions.text: A 20-year-old female university soccer player is injured during a match. While rapidly decelerating and attempting a sudden cutting maneuver, she feels a sharp, immediate pain in her knee and reports hearing a distinct pop sound. She is unable to continue playing due to instability and rapid swelling of the joint, which occurs within the first few hours. A maneuver is performed at clinic. What is the most likely diagnosis after the maneuver?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Tear

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with complaints of easy fatigability and recurrent infections. Examination shows massive splenomegaly but no significant lymphadenopathy. CBC shows: Hb 9 g/dL, WBC 2,500/µL, Platelets 70,000/µL. Peripheral smear shows the following blood picture. Bone marrow aspiration is “dry tap” due to fibrosis. Which of the following markers will not be seen on flowcytometry?

choices.text: It usually shows hemorrhage and necrosis
It belongs to the non-germ cell

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents with a painless, gradually enlarging testicular mass. On examination, the mass is firm and non-tender. Ultrasound shows a homogeneous hypoechoic lesion in the testis. Serum studies reveal:

AFP: Normal
β-hCG: Mildly elevated LDH: Elevated
Histopathology shows large round cells with clear cytoplasm, central nuclei with prominent nucleoli arranged in sheets, separated by fibrous septa infiltrated by lymphocytes. Which of the following statements is true regarding this tumor?

choices.text: Aplastic crisis due to parvovirus B19

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with complaints of dark-colored urine in the morning, easy fatigability, and episodes of abdominal pain. On examination, he is pale with mild hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory findings Hb: 7.8 g/dL, Reticulocyte count: Increased, LDH: Elevated, Direct Coombs test: Negative. Flow cytometry of peripheral blood shows a population of RBCs and granulocytes deficient in CD55 and CD59 expression. Which of the following complications is the most characteristic and life-threatening in this patient?

A 55-year-old male presents with splenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Flow cytometry shows cells positive for CD19, CD20, CD5, Cyclin D1, and negative for CD23. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old male develops autoimmune hepatitis. Hepatocytes show apoptosis with Councilman bodies on biopsy. Further studies reveal activation of caspase-3, triggered by the extrinsic death receptor pathway. Which of the following correctly matches the initiator caspase and executioner caspase involved in this pathway?

A 62-year-old man presents with progressive knee pain for the past 10 years, worsened by movement and relieved by rest. Radiographs show narrowing of the joint space with erosion of articular surfaces. Synovial fluid analysis reveals reduced viscosity. Which extracellular matrix component is most likely reduced, leading to loss of compressibility and lubrication of the articular cartilage?

A 52-year-old woman presents with progressive fatigue and intense pruritus. On examination, she has mild icterus and xanthelasma over eyelids. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase and cholesterol levels. Serology is positive for antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA). Liver biopsy shows granulomatous destruction of interlobular bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old man presents with a neck mass. FNAC shows malignant cells with salt-and-pepper chromatin. Congo red staining of the biopsy highlights amyloid deposits. Genetic testing reveals a RET proto-oncogene mutation. Which of the following syndromes may be associated with this condition?

A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive tightening of the skin over her fingers and face. She also complains of exertional dyspnea. Examination shows sclerodactyly and digital ulcers. HRCT chest reveals interstitial fibrosis. Serology is positive for anti–Scl-70 (anti–topoisomerase I) antibodies. Which of the following complications is most likely in this patient?

A 38-year-old woman presents with Raynaud’s phenomenon and skin tightening limited to her hands and face. She has esophageal dysmotility with reflux symptoms. Antibody testing shows positivity for anticentromere antibodies. Which of the following is she most likely at risk of developing?

A 42-year-old man presents with a persistent unpleasant taste in his mouth for the past 1 month. On examination, there are white, corrugated plaques along the lateral borders of the tongue that cannot be scraped off. Biopsy image is given below. In situ hybridization for Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) is positive. Which of the following underlying conditions is the most likely risk factor for this lesion?

A 38-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening abdominal distention and pain for 6 weeks. Imaging reveals an obstructive mass in the jejunum. Resection of the mass shows sheets of medium-sized lymphoid cells with multiple basophilic cytoplasmic vacuoles and a very high mitotic index. Flow cytometry demonstrates a monoclonal B-cell population. FISH analysis detects a chromosomal translocation involving chromosome 8. Which of the following oncogenes is most likely activated in this tumor?

A 72-year-old man presents with multiple, slowly enlarging, pigmented lesions on his trunk that have been present for many years. On examination, the lesions appear well-circumscribed, round to oval, and have a “stuck-on” appearance. One lesion is excised. Histopathology shows sheets of basaloid cells with keratin-filled cysts (horn cysts), sharply demarcated from the surrounding epidermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea for the past 6 months. Chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly with pulmonary congestion. Bronchoalveolar lavage cytology reveals macrophages with coarse golden-brown granules that stain positive with Prussian blue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, cough, and conjunctivitis. Three days later, a reddish maculopapular rash appears on his face and spreads down to his trunk and extremities. Examination of the buccal mucosa reveals bluish-white pinpoint lesions with an erythematous halo. Which viral infection is most likely?
